The metaphor is continued in the word ῥυπαρία (ἅπ. λεγ. in N.T.): see below ii. 3, Isa. lxiv. 6 ‘our righteousness is as filthy rags,’ Zeeh. iii. 4 ἀφέλετε τὰ ἱμάτια τὰ ῥυπαρὰ ἀπ’ αὐτοῦ καὶ εἷπε πρὸς αὐτόν· Ἰδού ἀφῄρηκα τὰς ἀνομίας σου, καὶ ἐνδύσατε αὐτὸν ποδήρη, Job xiv. 4, Apoc. xxii. 11 ὁ ῥυπαρὸς ῥυπανθήτω. St. Paul uses the synonym μολυσμός 2 Cor. vii. 1 (filthi- ness of the flesh and spirit). Strictly speaking the word ῥύπος is used of the wax of the ear, as in Hippocrates and Clem. Al. I’aed. ii. p. 222 P. quoted by Heisen‚ who suggests that there may be an allusion to the purged ear, auriam removendae sordes sunt quae audiendi celeritatem 'impedire quemn ,· but it cannot be assumed without evidence that the derivative retained the original force of the simple word. The phrase σαρκὸς ἀπόθεσις ῥύπου is used of baptism in 1 Pet. iii. 21 3 and so Schegg would explain here ; but there is no reference here to a past event. The aorist participle is part and parcel of the command contained in the imperative δέξασθε, as in the quotations from St. Paul. Plutarch uses ῥυπαρία (like our ‘Shabbiness’) Of avarice (Mor. p. 60 D): the compounds ῥυπαρόψυχος, ῥυπαρογνώμων are found in Byzantine writers, Its precise force in our text will be con- sidered in the following note.

περισσείαν κακίας.] ‘ Overflowing (ebullition) of malice.' The meaning is best shown in the cognate phrase in Luke vi. 45 (‘ the evil man out of the evil treasure in his heart bringeth forth that which is evil ') ἐκ γὰρ τοῦ περισσεύματος τῆς καρδίας λαλεῖ τὸ στόμα αὐτοῦ. The only other passages in which περισσεία occurs in N.T. are Rom. v, 17 τὴν περισσείαν τῆς χάριτος ‘the superabundance of grace,' 2 Cor. viii. 2 ἡ περισσεία τῆς χαρᾶς...ε’περίσσεῑ·σεν εἶς τὸ πλοῦτος τῆς ἁπλότητος αὐτῶν ‘ the overflowing of their joy overflowed to (so as to make up) the wealth of their generosity‚' 2 Cor. x. 15 εἷς περισσείαν ‘ to overflowing ' (abundantly). The writer warns his readers against hasty and passionate words, against the outbreak of evil temper. Then comes the question whether ῥυπαρίαν is to be taken separately (Calvin, Bouman, Lange), or as governing κακίας along with περισσείαν. The fact that πᾶσαν is not repeated is in favour of the latter construction, which is supported by Matthaei's Schol. τὴν ἁμαρτίαν τὴν ῥυπαίνουσαν τὸν ἄνθρωπον φησί, τὴν ὡς περιττὴν οὖσαν ε’ν ἡμῖν.
